methods; 

“lighting-up hours” means the period commencing one half-hour after sunset on

“lit” means the emission of a continuous light or a light that flashes not less than

“manufacturer” means a person who manufactures a vehicle or has such a

“manufacturer’s plate” means a data plate affixed to a vehicle in the course of

“maximum continuous rated power” means the maximum net power of an 
electric drive train at direct current (DC) voltage, which a drive train can deliver 
over a period of 30 minutes as an average manufacturer’s declared value; 

“maximum design speed” means the manufacturer’s specified maximum design 
speed which a vehicle is incapable, by reason of its construction, of exceeding 
on a level road or track under its own power and from which it may not deviate 
by more than 10%; 

“maximum net power” means the maximum value of the net power measured at 
full load; 

“net power” means the power obtained on a test bench at the end of the 
crankshaft or its equivalent at the corresponding engine or motor speed with the 
auxiliaries and determined under reference atmospheric conditions; 

“powered personal transporter” has the meaning assigned to it in section 3 (as 
amended by section 16 of the Road Traffic Act 2024 (No. 10 of 2024)) of the 
Road Traffic Act 1961 (No. 24 of 1961)

(a) 

(b) 

(c) 

is provided with, or together with the wheel on which it is

is such that, when it is deflated and is subjected to a normal load,

and is of such thickness as to minimise, so far as is reasonably practicable, 
vibration when the vehicle is in motion, and is so designed, constructed and

“reflector” means a reflex reflector the reflected light of which is capable of 
being returned substantially within an angle not greater than 3 degrees with an 
imaginary line connecting the reflector and the source of the light; 

“retro-reflective marking material” means a surface or a device from which, 
when directionally illuminated, a relatively large portion of the incident radiation 
is retro-reflected; 

“soft tyre” means a tyre (other than a pneumatic tyre) of soft or elastic material, 
which material is either— 

(a) 

(b) 

continuous round the circumference of the wheel, or 

in segments so fitted that, so far as is reasonably practicable, no 
space is left between the ends thereof, 

and is of such thickness as to minimise, so far as is reasonably practicable, 
vibration when the vehicle is in motion, and is so designed, constructed and 
maintained as to be free from any defect which might in any way cause damage 
to the surface of a road; 

“weight unladen” means the weight of the vehicle excluding the driver or a load 
but including battery power supply units used to power the vehicle; 

“wheel”, in relation to a vehicle, means a wheel the tyre or rim of which, when 
the vehicle is in motion, is in contact with the ground.

title: ROAD TRAFFIC (ELECTRIC SCOOTERS) REGULATIONS 2024
heading: 16. (1) An electric scooter shall be fitted with two independent braking
text_raw:
16. (1) An electric scooter shall be fitted with two independent braking 
devices, with one acting on the front wheel and the other acting on the rear 
wheel. 

(2) Each braking device shall be operable by the driver without removing 

either hand from the steering control. 

(3) The combination of braking devices shall be capable of stopping the 
vehicle up to and including the maximum design gross vehicle weight in a safe, 
efficient and fast manner by achieving a minimum deceleration value of 3.5 
metres per second squared within the design speed range. 

(4) Where one braking device fails, the other shall be capable of reaching 
minimum deceleration of 44 per cent of braking effect as specified in paragraph 
(3) without affecting the trajectory of the vehicle. 

(5) The braking devices shall be operable at all vehicle speeds, including 

where the vehicle reaches maximum design speed. 

(6) The vehicle behaviour during braking shall be stable without excessive 

juddering and shall not impact the driver’s control or balance.

title: ROAD TRAFFIC (ELECTRIC SCOOTERS) REGULATIONS 2024
heading: 22. (1) An electric scooter and the components of its electrical system,
text_raw:
22. (1) An electric scooter and the components of its electrical system, 
including the battery, shall be so designed, constructed and maintained so as 
to— 

(a) 

protect against the risk of electrolyte leakage, fire, explosion and 
electric shock in all weather conditions, 

(b) protect against the risk of injury and danger to any person by the 

placing or insulating of electric cabling or connections, 

(c) 

(d) 

protect against any hazards arising from the charging system due 
to overloading, overcharge, overcurrent and over discharge, and 

ensure they pose no risk to human health or the safety of persons, 
to property or the environment. 

(2) Compliance with the requirements of paragraph (1) may be demonstrated 
by evidencing that the electric scooter complies with sections 6, 9, 10 and 11 of

text_raw:
24. (1) An electric scooter shall be equipped with wheels with a minimum 

diameter, including the tyre, of 200 mm. 

(2) A wheel on an electric scooter shall be fitted with pneumatic or soft tyres 

designed for adherence to the road and road use. 

(3) Each wheel on an electric scooter shall be so designed, constructed and 
maintained to adhere to the road and be capable of supporting the proportion of 
the design gross vehicle weight applicable to the relevant axle, at all vehicle 
speeds, including maximum design speed.

heading: 26. (1) The manufacturer of an electric scooter or his or her authorised
text_raw:
26. (1) The manufacturer of an electric scooter or his or her authorised 
distributor shall affix a manufacturer’s plate to that vehicle in a clearly visible 
location. 

(2) A manufacturer’s plate shall be unique to each electric scooter and shall 

not be reused on another vehicle. 

(3) A manufacturer’s plate shall be in a permanent form and shall remain 

affixed to the electric scooter during its lifetime. 

(4) A manufacturer’s plate shall contain the following information in relation 

to a vehicle—

heading: 27. (1) An electric scooter, being used in a public place, shall have the CE
text_raw:
27. (1) An electric scooter, being used in a public place, shall have the CE 
marking affixed to it in accordance with Regulation 11 of the European 
Communities (Machinery) Regulations 2008 (S. I. No. 407 of 2008).

title: ROAD TRAFFIC (ELECTRIC SCOOTERS) REGULATIONS 2024
heading: (This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal
text_raw:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations apply to electric scooters and prescribe the requirements, 
from 20 May 2024, for their construction, equipment and use while being 
operated in public places. The Regulations also prescribe conditions for the use 
of electric scooters and their equipment and the duties of drivers. 

In addition, these Regulations prescribe a maximum ordinary speed limit at 
which electric scooters may be driven from 20 May 2024 on a public road of 20 
km/h, except where a lower road speed limit applies. 

The Regulations further provide that the minimum age for use of an electric 
scooter on a public road is 16.
